clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city has a famous clock tower that chimes every hour.
It is home to the world’s oldest underground railway system.
fun_fact: Big Ben is actually the nickname for the bell inside the clock tower, not the tower itself!
London has over 170 museums, including the British Museum, which has over 8 million objects.
trivia: This city hosted the Olympics three times, more than any other city.
The River Thames has over 200 bridges crossing it.

clues: An ancient amphitheater in this city once hosted gladiator fights.
This city is home to the smallest country in the world.
fun_fact: The Colosseum could hold up to 50,000 spectators at its peak!
Vatican City, the smallest country in the world, is entirely within Rome.
trivia: Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world.
The city's nickname is 'The Eternal City' because of its long history.

clues: This city has an iconic opera house with a unique sail-like design.
One of the largest natural harbors in the world is located here.
fun_fact: Sydney’s harbor is deep enough to fit seven Empire State Buildings stacked on top of each other!
The Sydney Opera House's roof is covered with over 1 million tiles.
trivia: Bondi Beach in this city is one of the most famous beaches in the world.
Sydney was founded as a British penal colony in 1788.

clues: Home to the world’s tallest building, which pierces the sky.
This city has an artificial archipelago shaped like a palm tree.
fun_fact: The Burj Khalifa is so tall that you can watch the sunset twice from different floors!
Dubai has no natural rivers, but it has plenty of man-made canals and islands.
trivia: This city has the world’s largest indoor ski resort, despite being in a desert.
Gold vending machines exist here, allowing people to buy gold bars like snacks.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant street markets and floating markets.
It has a temple with a giant reclining Buddha statue.
fun_fact: Bangkok’s full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world!
Tuk-tuks, a popular mode of transport here, were originally imported from Japan.
trivia: This city attracts more tourists than any other in the world.
The Grand Palace in Bangkok was built in 1782 and has been home to the Thai King ever since.

clues: This city has one of the tallest free-standing towers in the world.
It is known for its diverse culture and film festival.
fun_fact: Toronto has over 10 million trees, giving it a green skyline!
The CN Tower was the tallest building in the world until 2009.
trivia: This city has an underground pedestrian walkway spanning 30 kilometers.
Toronto's name comes from a Mohawk word meaning 'place where trees stand in water.'

clues: This city is home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
A river runs through it, supporting civilization for thousands of years.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure for 3,800 years!
Cairo’s name means 'The Victorious' in Arabic.
trivia: The Nile River, which runs through this city, is the longest river in the world.
Cairo has the oldest university in the world, Al-Azhar University, founded in 970 AD.

clues: This city was once divided by a wall that fell in 1989.
It is known for its vibrant art scene and historical landmarks.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice—over 1,700 in total!
The Berlin TV Tower is the tallest structure in Germany.
trivia: Berlin's underground train system has one of the longest networks in the world.
This city is home to over 150 museums.

clues: Home to a famous red square with a colorful cathedral.
This city has the largest metro system in Europe.
fun_fact: Moscow's metro stations are known as the 'palaces of the people' due to their stunning architecture!
The city experiences extreme weather, with winter temperatures dropping below -30°C.
trivia: Moscow's Kremlin is home to the Russian president.
The Moscow Metro serves over 9 million passengers daily.

clues: This city is famous for tango dancing and its passionate football fans.
It has one of the widest avenues in the world.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has over 300 theaters, making it one of the world's theater capitals!
The city has a bookstore inside a former opera house, considered one of the most beautiful in the world.
trivia: This city is known as the 'Paris of South America' due to its European-style architecture.
Buenos Aires is home to one of the largest cemeteries in the world, La Recoleta.

clues: This city sits on two continents, Europe and Asia.
It is home to a famous blue mosque.
fun_fact: Istanbul was formerly called Byzantium and Constantinople!
The Grand Bazaar here is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world.
trivia: The Bosphorus Strait divides the city between two continents.
Istanbul is the only city in the world that has served as the capital of three different empires: Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman.

clues: This city is known for its K-pop culture and high-tech innovations.
It has a palace that was once home to Korean kings.
fun_fact: Seoul has the fastest internet speeds in the world!
The city’s subway system has heated seats for cold winters.
trivia: The Namsan Tower offers a breathtaking view of the city.
Seoul's street food scene is famous worldwide, especially for tteokbokki and kimchi.

clues: This city was built on top of an ancient Aztec capital.
It has a floating garden system called Xochimilco.
fun_fact: Mexico City is sinking at a rate of about 50 cm per year!
It has the largest number of museums of any city in the Americas.
trivia: The city's main square, Zócalo, is one of the largest in the world.
Mexico City has an underground pyramid beneath a cathedral.

clues: This city is famous for its flat-topped mountain.
It has a historic prison island where Nelson Mandela was once held.
fun_fact: Cape Town's Table Mountain has more plant species than the entire UK!
The city’s beaches offer views of both the Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
trivia: The Cape of Good Hope is near this city.
Cape Town is home to the oldest wine-producing region in the Southern Hemisphere.

clues: This city-state is known for its futuristic skyline and cleanliness.
It has a famous hotel with an infinity pool on the rooftop.
fun_fact: Singapore has a man-made waterfall inside an airport!
Chewing gum is banned in Singapore to keep the city clean.
trivia: This city has a night safari, the first of its kind in the world.
Singapore’s national symbol is the Merlion, a mythical creature with a lion’s head and a fish’s body.

clues: This city has a massive statue overlooking it from a mountain.
It is famous for its vibrant carnival celebrations.
fun_fact: The city's beaches, like Copacabana, are among the most famous in the world!
Rio de Janeiro was the capital of Brazil until 1960.
trivia: This city hosted the Summer Olympics in 2016.
The Maracanã Stadium here once held the record for the highest football match attendance.

clues: This city is home to a famous sign on the hills.
It is the entertainment capital of the world.
fun_fact: Los Angeles is home to more than 100 museums!
The city’s Griffith Observatory offers one of the best views of the night sky.
trivia: Hollywood, the center of the movie industry, is located here.
Los Angeles hosted the Olympics in 1932 and 1984 and will host them again in 2028.

clues: This city is the capital of a country known for flamenco and paella.
It has a famous square called Puerta del Sol.
fun_fact: Madrid has the oldest restaurant in the world, founded in 1725!
This city has more green space per resident than most other European capitals.
trivia: The Royal Palace of Madrid has over 3,400 rooms.
Madrid is home to one of the world's best football clubs, Real Madrid.

clues: This city is home to an ancient temple dedicated to Athena.
It hosted the first modern Olympic Games.
fun_fact: Athens is one of the oldest cities in the world, with over 3,400 years of history!
The Acropolis was once brightly colored, not just white marble.
trivia: The word 'marathon' comes from a historic battle near this city.
Athens has more theaters than any other city in the world.

clues: This city has a massive square and an ancient palace complex.
It hosted the Summer Olympics in 2008 and the Winter Olympics in 2022.
fun_fact: The Forbidden City has around 9,000 rooms and was home to Chinese emperors for centuries!
Beijing’s subway system is one of the busiest in the world.
trivia: This city is home to part of the Great Wall of China.
Beijing duck is one of the most famous dishes originating from this city.

clues: This city is famous for its classical music composers like Mozart and Beethoven.
It has one of the oldest amusement parks in the world.
fun_fact: Vienna has been ranked as the most livable city in the world multiple times!
The city’s famous coffee houses are part of UNESCO’s cultural heritage list.
trivia: The Schönbrunn Palace has over 1,400 rooms.
Vienna's Prater Park is home to the iconic Giant Ferris Wheel.

clues: This city is built on 14 islands connected by over 50 bridges.
It is known for hosting the annual Nobel Prize ceremony.
fun_fact: Stockholm’s metro stations are called the 'world’s longest art gallery' due to their unique designs!
The city was founded over 750 years ago.
trivia: The Vasa Museum here contains a nearly intact 17th-century warship.
Stockholm’s Old Town, Gamla Stan, is one of the best-preserved medieval city centers in Europe.

clues: This city is home to a famous red fort and a tall minaret.
It serves as the capital of a country known for its diverse culture.
fun_fact: New Delhi was designed by British architects and completed in 1931!
The Lotus Temple here is shaped like a blooming flower and welcomes visitors of all faiths.
trivia: The India Gate war memorial is one of the city's most visited landmarks.
New Delhi’s metro system is one of the largest in the world.

clues: This city is surrounded by fjords and forests.
It is known for its Viking heritage.
fun_fact: Oslo has a museum dedicated entirely to Viking ships!
The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded in this city every year.
trivia: The city is one of the greenest capitals in the world.
Oslo was founded over 1,000 years ago.

clues: This city is known for its canals and cycling culture.
It has a famous museum dedicated to Vincent van Gogh.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has more bicycles than people!
The city was built on wooden poles driven into the ground.
trivia: The Anne Frank House is one of the most visited museums here.
Amsterdam has over 1,500 bridges.

clues: This city is known for its yellow trams and hilly streets.
It was almost completely rebuilt after a massive earthquake in 1755.
fun_fact: Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world, predating Rome and London!
The city’s Belém Tower was built in the 16th century.
trivia: Lisbon is the westernmost capital of mainland Europe.
It has a bridge longer than the Golden Gate Bridge.

clues: This city is known for its saunas and design district.
It is one of the northernmost capitals in the world.
fun_fact: Helsinki has around 3 million saunas, more than one per household!
The city is built on a peninsula with over 300 islands.
trivia: Helsinki hosted the Summer Olympics in 1952.
The city's Rock Church is built directly into solid rock.

clues: This city is the capital of the world's largest island country.
It has a monument called Monas at its center.
fun_fact: Jakarta is sinking at one of the fastest rates in the world!
The city has a diverse mix of cultures, including Javanese, Sundanese, and Betawi.
trivia: Jakarta was formerly known as Batavia during Dutch rule.
It is the largest city in Southeast Asia.

clues: This city is known as the 'Safari Capital of the World'.
It is one of the few capitals with a national park within its borders.
fun_fact: Nairobi National Park is home to lions, giraffes, and rhinos!
The city was founded as a railway supply depot in the 19th century.
trivia: Nairobi’s name comes from a Maasai phrase meaning 'cool water'.
This city has one of Africa’s tallest skyscrapers, the Britam Tower.

clues: This city is the capital of a country famous for its coffee and emeralds.
It has a high-altitude location in the Andes mountains.
fun_fact: Bogotá is one of the highest capital cities in the world, sitting at 2,640 meters above sea level!
The city has a weekly event called 'Ciclovía', where main roads are closed for cyclists and pedestrians.
trivia: Bogotá is home to the largest network of bike paths in Latin America.
The city's Gold Museum has the largest collection of pre-Hispanic gold artifacts in the world.

clues: This city is known for its historic colonial architecture and coastal location.
It is the gateway to the famous ruins of Machu Picchu.
fun_fact: Lima was once the most important city in South America during Spanish rule!
The city has one of the world’s oldest universities, founded in 1551.
trivia: Lima is the only capital in South America located on the Pacific Ocean.
It is famous for its ceviche, a popular seafood dish.

clues: This city is home to the tallest twin towers in the world.
It has a mix of Malay, Chinese, and Indian influences.
fun_fact: The name 'Kuala Lumpur' means 'muddy confluence' in Malay, referring to the city’s founding at the meeting of two rivers!
The city’s Petronas Towers were once the tallest buildings in the world.
trivia: Kuala Lumpur has one of the largest shopping malls in the world, Berjaya Times Square.
The Batu Caves, just outside the city, feature a giant golden statue of Lord Murugan.

clues: This city is known for its stunning architecture by Antoni Gaudí.
It has one of the most famous football clubs in the world.
fun_fact: Barcelona’s Sagrada Familia has been under construction since 1882!
The city has its own language, Catalan, alongside Spanish.
trivia: Barcelona has more than 55 museums.
It was the first city to win a Royal Gold Medal for architecture.

clues: This city hosts the world-famous Oktoberfest beer festival.
It is home to one of the most successful football clubs in Europe.
fun_fact: Munich’s airport has a full-size wave pool for surfing!
The city's English Garden is larger than New York's Central Park.
trivia: Munich was the birthplace of BMW.
The Glockenspiel in Marienplatz performs daily chimes and a show.

clues: This city is famous for its canals and gondola rides.
It hosts an iconic annual carnival with elaborate masks.
fun_fact: Venice is built on over 100 small islands connected by bridges!
The city is slowly sinking due to rising sea levels.
trivia: Venice was once a powerful maritime republic.
The city has no roads—only canals and footpaths.

clues: This city is a global fashion capital.
It is home to one of the most famous cathedrals in the world.
fun_fact: Milan’s La Scala is one of the most famous opera houses globally!
The city hosts one of the world’s biggest fashion weeks.
trivia: Leonardo da Vinci's 'The Last Supper' is housed in Milan.
Milan is Italy’s second-largest city by population.

clues: This city is known as the birthplace of the Renaissance.
It is home to Michelangelo’s famous statue of David.
fun_fact: Florence was once one of the richest cities in medieval Europe!
The city's Ponte Vecchio bridge has shops built directly on it.
trivia: Florence's Uffizi Gallery is one of the world's most famous art museums.
The Medici family ruled Florence for centuries and influenced its culture.

clues: This city is home to one of the oldest astronomical clocks in the world.
It is known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires'.
fun_fact: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle in the world!
The Charles Bridge has been standing since the 14th century.
trivia: Prague was once the capital of the Holy Roman Empire.
Its historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: This city was almost completely destroyed during World War II but was rebuilt.
It is known for its beautiful Old Town and historic palaces.
fun_fact: Warsaw’s Old Town was reconstructed using paintings and photographs!
The city’s Palace of Culture and Science is one of the tallest buildings in Poland.
trivia: Warsaw is sometimes called the 'Phoenix City' due to its rebirth.
The city is home to one of the world’s largest Chopin music festivals.

clues: This city is split into two parts by the Danube River.
It is famous for its thermal baths and stunning parliament building.
fun_fact: Budapest has the oldest underground metro system in mainland Europe!
The city’s thermal springs supply over 100 baths and spas.
trivia: Budapest was originally two separate cities: Buda and Pest.
The Chain Bridge was the first permanent bridge connecting Buda and Pest.

clues: This city is known as the capital of the European Union.
It is famous for its waffles, chocolates, and Manneken Pis statue.
fun_fact: Brussels has over 2,000 chocolate shops!
The city’s Atomium was built for the 1958 World Expo.
trivia: Brussels is home to the headquarters of NATO.
The Grand Place is one of the most beautiful squares in Europe.

clues: This city is Switzerland’s financial hub.
It is known for its picturesque lake and mountains.
fun_fact: Zurich has consistently been ranked among the world’s most livable cities!
The city hosts one of the largest techno music festivals in the world.
trivia: Zurich’s Bahnhofstrasse is one of the world’s most expensive shopping streets.
The city has a vibrant arts scene, with over 50 museums.

clues: This city is home to the headquarters of the United Nations in Europe.
It is famous for its large lake and stunning mountain views.
fun_fact: The Jet d'Eau fountain shoots water 140 meters into the air!
Geneva is known for its high-quality Swiss watches.
trivia: The city hosts the largest particle physics lab in the world, CERN.
Geneva has been a center for diplomacy for centuries.

clues: This city is famous for its colorful Nyhavn harbor.
It is home to a famous statue inspired by a fairytale.
fun_fact: The Little Mermaid statue is one of the most visited landmarks in the city!
Copenhagen is one of the most bike-friendly cities in the world.
trivia: The city’s Tivoli Gardens is one of the world’s oldest amusement parks.
Danish pastries were actually inspired by Austrian bakers.

clues: This city is famous for its literary heritage and historic pubs.
It is home to a famous dark beer enjoyed worldwide.
fun_fact: The Guinness Storehouse is one of the most visited attractions in Ireland!
Dublin has more than 750 pubs, many dating back centuries.
trivia: Dublin’s Trinity College Library holds the famous Book of Kells.
The city’s name comes from the Irish 'Dubh Linn,' meaning 'Black Pool.'

clues: This city hosts the world’s largest arts festival every summer.
It is home to a historic castle perched on a volcanic rock.
fun_fact: The Edinburgh Festival Fringe attracts artists from all over the world!
The city’s Old Town and New Town are both UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
trivia: J.K. Rowling wrote much of 'Harry Potter' in Edinburgh cafés.
Edinburgh’s Hogmanay celebration is one of the biggest New Year’s festivals in the world.

clues: This city is Scotland’s largest and known for its vibrant music scene.
It is home to one of the oldest universities in the English-speaking world.
fun_fact: Glasgow was once known as the 'Second City of the British Empire' due to its industrial strength!
The city has one of the best live music scenes in the UK.
trivia: Glasgow’s underground metro system is the third oldest in the world.
The city’s motto is 'Let Glasgow Flourish.'
